text: Nuclear transcription factors that bind to elements of the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
Induction requirements in primary human T cells .
Prior studies have identified several elements that contribute to the activity of the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter in the stimulated T cell line , Jurkat .
The sites and their corresponding nuclear binding factors include : NF-kappa B , AP-1 , AP-3 , <extra_id_0> OCT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and NF-AT .
The latter " nuclear factor for activated T cells " likely contributes to the tissue specificity of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression .

text: Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays , we have studied these transcription factors in primary T cells from human blood to verify their presence in a physiologic setting and to identify the signals that stimulate factor activity .
All factors are induced in the nuclei of T cells upon activation with mitogens but not with exogenous <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> growth factor .
However , the signaling requirements and sensitivity to protein synthesis inhibitors differ considerably .

Only the activities for NF-AT and AP-1 sites require two signals for optimal induction , i.e . , PMA plus either lectin or antibody to the CD3 or <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> surface molecules .
Other factors are induced by lectin , antibody , and / or PMA alone .
After appropriate stimulation , both NF-AT and AP-1 are peculiarly sensitive to the protein synthesis inhibitor anisomycin .
Our data correlate the activity of NF-AT and AP-1 in gel shift assays with the two signals requirements for <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression .
